articles.headline: Muddled Intelligence Hampered Response to Capitol Riot
articles.snippet: New details about what authorities anticipated on Jan. 6 highlight failures to grasp the degree of the threat from pro-Trump right-wing extremists.
articles.abstract: New details about what authorities anticipated on Jan. 6 highlight failures to grasp the degree of the threat from pro-Trump right-wing extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Jan. 4, the intelligence division of the United States Capitol Police issued a report listing all the groups known to be descending on the city and planning to rally for President Donald J. Trump two days later, such as the Prime Time Patriots, the MAGA Marchers and Stop the Steal.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Lou Dobbs’s Show Is Canceled by Fox Business
articles.snippet: Mr. Dobbs, a loyal supporter of former President Donald J. Trump, was named in a $2.7 billion lawsuit filed on Thursday against the Fox Corporation and two other Fox anchors.
articles.abstract: Mr. Dobbs, a loyal supporter of former President Donald J. Trump, was named in a $2.7 billion lawsuit filed on Thursday against the Fox Corporation and two other Fox anchors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lou Dobbs, one of former President Donald J. Trump’s most loyal media supporters, abruptly lost his pulpit on Friday when Fox Business canceled his weekday television show, which had become a frequent clearinghouse for baseless theories of electoral fraud in the weeks after Mr. Trump lost the 2020 presidential race.

articles.headline: With Economy in ‘Crisis,’ Biden Is Ready to Bypass G.O.P. on Stimulus
articles.snippet: President Biden said the economy was in trouble and warned Republicans that he would move ahead with a $1.9 trillion aid package with or without their support.
articles.abstract: President Biden said the economy was in trouble and warned Republicans that he would move ahead with a $1.9 trillion aid package with or without their support.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden, spurred on by a lackluster January jobs report and Democratic support for his $1.9 trillion economic aid proposal, said on Friday that the economy was in need of urgent help and that Republicans should either get on board with a robust stimulus package or expect his plan to pass without their support.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: HNA Was Once China’s Biggest Dealmaker. Now It Faces Bankruptcy.
articles.snippet: China is tightening the reins on its economy and looking out for companies that could pose risks to China’s financial system.
articles.abstract: China is tightening the reins on its economy and looking out for companies that could pose risks to China’s financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Its lenders are pushing for bankruptcy. Its chairman and co-founder has been quietly stripped of power. Nearly $10 billion of its money has been embezzled.

articles.headline: How the United States Lost to Hackers
articles.snippet: America’s biggest vulnerability in cyberwarfare is hubris.
articles.abstract: America’s biggest vulnerability in cyberwarfare is hubris.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Migrant Families Force Biden to Confront New Border Crisis
articles.snippet: In recent days, hundreds of migrant families have been released into the United States by Border Patrol agents. Thousands more are hoping for a chance to enter under looser policies.
articles.abstract: In recent days, hundreds of migrant families have been released into the United States by Border Patrol agents. Thousands more are hoping for a chance to enter under looser policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — President Biden’s first immigration crisis has already begun as thousands of families have surged toward the southwestern border in recent weeks, propelled by expectations of a friendlier reception and by a change in Mexican policy that makes it harder for the United States to expel some of the migrants.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Max Rivlin-Nadler

articles.headline: To Fight or Hide: Fear Grips Myanmar With Military Back in Charge
articles.snippet: Dozens of arrests, beatings by mysterious thugs and telecommunication cutoffs are the new reality across the country. But civil disobedience defiantly persists.
articles.abstract: Dozens of arrests, beatings by mysterious thugs and telecommunication cutoffs are the new reality across the country. But civil disobedience defiantly persists.
articles.lead_paragraph: The red balloons rose over an anxious city. They floated by the hundreds above the golden spire of Sule Pagoda in Yangon, the commercial capital of Myanmar, and drifted over an avenue where, more than a dozen years ago, soldiers shot citizens marching peacefully for democracy.

articles.headline: Pushing QAnon and Stolen Election Lies, Flynn Re-emerges
articles.snippet: Recast by President Trump’s most ardent supporters as a MAGA martyr, Michael T. Flynn has embraced his role as the man who spent four years unjustly ensnared in the Russia investigation.
articles.abstract: Recast by President Trump’s most ardent supporters as a MAGA martyr, Michael T. Flynn has embraced his role as the man who spent four years unjustly ensnared in the Russia investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Washington’s respectable circles, Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, is a discredited and dishonored ex-general, a once-esteemed military intelligence officer who went off the rails ideologically and then was fired a mere 24 days into the Trump administration for lying to the F.B.I. about contacts with the Russian ambassador.

articles.headline: Pandemic’s Toll on Housing: Falling Behind, Doubling Up
articles.snippet: Eviction moratoriums don’t keep arrears from piling up, and aid to renters may not reach the most vulnerable.
articles.abstract: Eviction moratoriums don’t keep arrears from piling up, and aid to renters may not reach the most vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the pandemic enters its second year, millions of renters are struggling with a loss of income and with the insecurity of not knowing how long they will have a home. Their savings depleted, they are running up credit card debt to make the rent, or accruing months of overdue payments. Families are moving in together, offsetting the cost of housing by finding others to share it.

articles.headline: Lawsuits Take the Lead in Fight Against Disinformation
articles.snippet: Defamation cases have made waves across an uneasy right-wing media landscape, from Fox to Newsmax.
articles.abstract: Defamation cases have made waves across an uneasy right-wing media landscape, from Fox to Newsmax.
articles.lead_paragraph: In just a few weeks, lawsuits and legal threats from a pair of obscure election technology companies have achieved what years of advertising boycotts, public pressure campaigns and liberal outrage could not: curbing the flow of misinformation in right-wing media.

articles.headline: The Working Woman’s Anthem ‘9 to 5’ Needed an Update. But This?
articles.snippet: A Super Bowl ad has remade Dolly Parton’s feminist classic into an ode to hustle culture. It isn’t quite as empowering as the original.
articles.abstract: A Super Bowl ad has remade Dolly Parton’s feminist classic into an ode to hustle culture. It isn’t quite as empowering as the original.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1978, when Jane Fonda decided she wanted to make a film about working women, she traveled to Cleveland to meet with members of an organization that would come to be known as 9to5. The women were clerical workers who were fed up with low wages and chauvinist managers, and Ms. Fonda asked them: “Have you ever fantasized about killing your boss?”

articles.headline: The Hopes That Rose and Fell With GameStop
articles.snippet: Fueled by amateur traders and online enthusiasm, the struggling retailer’s shares took investors on a ride like no other. For them, it ended in different ways, including apathy, defiance and regret.
articles.abstract: Fueled by amateur traders and online enthusiasm, the struggling retailer’s shares took investors on a ride like no other. For them, it ended in different ways, including apathy, defiance and regret.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some wanted to be on the front lines of a revolution. Some wanted to be rich. And by the end of a wild two-week ride where fortunes were made and lost, some just hoped they’d be able to pay their rent.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips, Taylor Lorenz, Tara Siegel Bernard and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: Why Chuck Schumer Is Cozying Up to the A.O.C. Wing of His Party
articles.snippet: As he prepares for an impeachment trial this week, Senator Chuck Schumer is at the height of his political power in Washington. At home in New York, he is taking steps to head off a primary challenge from the left.
articles.abstract: As he prepares for an impeachment trial this week, Senator Chuck Schumer is at the height of his political power in Washington. At home in New York, he is taking steps to head off a primary challenge from the left.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday evening, about a dozen liberal housing activists from New York gathered for a virtual meeting with Senator Chuck Schumer. Though the newly anointed majority leader had served in Congress for four decades, a number of participants had scarcely interacted with him before, and some regarded him as an uncertain ally.

articles.headline: George P. Shultz, Top Cabinet Official Under Nixon and Reagan, Dies at 100
articles.snippet: He carried one of Washington’s weightiest résumés — labor secretary, treasury secretary and budget director for Nixon and secretary of state under Reagan as the Cold War waned.
articles.abstract: He carried one of Washington’s weightiest résumés — labor secretary, treasury secretary and budget director for Nixon and secretary of state under Reagan as the Cold War waned.
articles.lead_paragraph: George P. Shultz, who presided with a steady hand over the beginning of the end of the Cold War as President Ronald Reagan’s often embattled secretary of state, died on Saturday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 100.

articles.headline: Where Do Vaccine Doses Go, and Who Gets Them? The Algorithms Decide
articles.snippet: Health agencies and hospitals are using different formulas to allocate the coronavirus shots, exacerbating disparities in vaccine access.
articles.abstract: Health agencies and hospitals are using different formulas to allocate the coronavirus shots, exacerbating disparities in vaccine access.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Impeachment Case Aims to Marshal Outrage of Capitol Attack Against Trump
articles.snippet: Armed with lessons from the last impeachment trial of Donald J. Trump, prosecutors plan a shorter, video-heavy presentation to confront Republicans with the fury they felt around the Capitol riot.
articles.abstract: Armed with lessons from the last impeachment trial of Donald J. Trump, prosecutors plan a shorter, video-heavy presentation to confront Republicans with the fury they felt around the Capitol riot.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Impeachment trial video and analysis.]

articles.headline: Big Publishing Pushes Out Trump’s Last Fan
articles.snippet: Top editors at Hachette have told employees that they’ve learned the lessons of the Capitol siege of Jan. 6: no hate speech, no incitement to violence, no false narratives.
articles.abstract: Top editors at Hachette have told employees that they’ve learned the lessons of the Capitol siege of Jan. 6: no hate speech, no incitement to violence, no false narratives.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you were a certain kind of distinctly Trumpy public figure — say Donald Trump Jr. or Corey Lewandowski — looking to sell a book over the last four years, there were surprisingly few options. The Big Five publishing companies in New York, and even their dedicated conservative imprints, had become squeamish about the genre known as MAGA books, with its divisive politics and relaxed approach to facts. And small conservative publishers probably couldn’t afford you.

articles.headline: Dying of Covid in a ‘Separate and Unequal’ L.A. Hospital
articles.snippet: Inside an overwhelmed facility in the worst-hit part of California, where the patriarchs of two immigrant families were taken when they fell sick.
articles.abstract: Inside an overwhelmed facility in the worst-hit part of California, where the patriarchs of two immigrant families were taken when they fell sick.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Sheri Fink and Isadora Kosofsky

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Most Reviled Investors Worry About Their Fate
articles.snippet: Short sellers — self-described financial detectives who make money when companies fail — were already worried about their success and safety. Then GameStop happened.
articles.abstract: Short sellers — self-described financial detectives who make money when companies fail — were already worried about their success and safety. Then GameStop happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fahmi Quadir fears for her safety, so whenever she travels, she shares her GPS coordinates with her lawyer and a colleague. Nate Koppikar was once tailed by a private investigator into the bathroom in his own office. And Gabe Plotkin recently hired security after threats to his family.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: ‘We Are Forgotten’: Grocery Workers Hope for Higher Pay and Vaccinations
articles.snippet: Booming business during the pandemic hasn’t always meant better wages, and they have largely been left off vaccine priority lists.
articles.abstract: Booming business during the pandemic hasn’t always meant better wages, and they have largely been left off vaccine priority lists.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been an exhausting 10 months for Toni Ward Sockwell, an assistant manager at Cash Saver, a grocery chain, in Guthrie, Okla. She has been helping to oversee about 40 anxious employees during a deadly pandemic, vigilantly disinfecting counters at the store and worrying about passing the coronavirus to her elderly mother while dropping off produce.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: In China, an App Offered Space for Debate. Then the Censors Came.
articles.snippet: For a little while, the social media platform Clubhouse provided the rare opportunity for cross-border dialogue on contentious topics free from the country’s usual tight controls.
articles.abstract: For a little while, the social media platform Clubhouse provided the rare opportunity for cross-border dialogue on contentious topics free from the country’s usual tight controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: One by one, the chatroom participants took the digital microphone as thousands quietly listened in.
articles.byline: By Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
